passages.1:1: Proverbs of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel:
passages.1:2: To know wisdom and instruction, to understand sayings of understanding,
passages.1:3: to gain {insightful instruction},<note: Literally "the instruction of insight"> righteousness and justice and equity,
passages.1:4: to give shrewdness<note: Or "cleverness," or "prudence"> to the simple, knowledge and purpose<note: Or "plan"> to the young,
passages.1:5: may the wise hear and increase learning, and the one who understands gain direction,<note: Or "guidance">
passages.1:6: to understand a proverb and an expression, words of wisdom and their riddles.
passages.1:7: Fear of Yahweh [is the] beginning of knowledge; wisdom and instruction, fools despise.
passages.1:8: My child, may you keep<note: Or "obey," or "hear"> your father's instruction, and do not reject your mother's teachings,
passages.1:9: for they [are] a garland of favor for your head, and pendants for your neck.
passages.1:10: My child, if sinners entice you, do not consent.
passages.1:11: If they say, "Come with us! We shall lie in wait for blood; we shall ambush the innocent without cause.<note: Or "wantonly," or "for nothing">
passages.1:12: Like Sheol,<note: A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld> we will swallow them alive and whole, {like those who descend to the pit}.<note: Literally "like the descenders of a pit">
passages.1:13: We shall find all precious wealth, we shall fill our houses [with] booty,
passages.1:14: you shall throw your lot in our midst, there will be one purse for all of us."
passages.1:15: My child, do not walk in their way.<note: Or "on their road"> Keep your foot from their paths,
passages.1:16: for their feet run to evil, and they hurry to shed blood,
passages.1:17: for "in vain<note: Or "without cause," or "for nothing"> is the net scattered, in the sight of any {winged bird}."<note: Literally "bird of wing">
passages.1:18: They lie in wait for their [own] blood. They ambush their [own] lives.
passages.1:19: Thus are the ways of all who are greedy [for] gain-- it will take the life of its possessors.
passages.1:20: Wisdom calls out in the streets, in the squares she raises her voice.
passages.1:21: On a {busy corner}<note: Literally "head of commotion," or "head of stirring, bustling"> she cries out, at the entrances of the gates in the city, she speaks her sayings:
passages.1:22: "{How long},<note: Literally "Until when"> O simple ones, will you love simplicity? And [how long] will scoffers delight in their scoffing, and fools hate knowledge?
passages.1:23: May you turn to my argument!<note: Or "turn at my reproach"> Behold, I shall pour out my spirit upon you; I will make my words known to you.
passages.1:24: Because I called out and you refused me, I stretched out my hand, yet there is none who heeds.
passages.1:25: You have ignored all my counsel, and my reproof you are not willing [to accept].
passages.1:26: I will also laugh at your calamity;<note: Or "downfall"> I will mock when panic<note: Or "dread, fear"> comes [upon] you.
passages.1:27: When your panic comes like a storm, and your calamity arrives like a whirlwind, when distress and anguish come upon you,
passages.1:28: then they will call<note: Or "cry out [to]"> me, but I will not answer; they will seek me diligently but not find me.
passages.1:29: Since they hated knowledge, and did not choose the fear of Yahweh,
passages.1:30: they were not willing [to accept] my counsel, they despised all my reproof.
passages.1:31: They shall eat from the fruit of their way, and they shall be sated from their own schemes,
passages.1:32: for the waywardness of the simple ones will kill them, and the complacency of fools will destroy them.
passages.1:33: Whoever listens to me will dwell in security and rest securely<note: Or "be at ease, peace"> from dread and disaster."
passages.2:1: My child, if you will receive<note: Or "take, seize"> my sayings, and hide my commands with you,
passages.2:2: [in order] to incline your ear toward wisdom, [then] you shall apply your heart to understanding.
passages.2:3: For if you cry out for understanding,<note: Or "call to understanding"> [if] you lift<note: Or "carry, give"> your voice for insight,
passages.2:4: if you seek her like silver and search her out {like treasure},<note: Literally "like the treasures">
passages.2:5: then you will understand the fear of Yahweh, and the knowledge of God you will find.
passages.2:6: For Yahweh will give wisdom; from his mouth [come] knowledge and understanding.
passages.2:7: For the upright, he stores<note: Or "hides, keeps"> sound judgment, a shield for those who walk uprightly,
passages.2:8: [in order] to guard paths of justice and keep<note: Or "preserve, guard, watch"> the way of his faithful [ones].
passages.2:9: Then you will understand righteousness and justice and uprightness--every good course--
passages.2:10: for wisdom will enter your heart, and knowledge will be pleasing to your soul.<note: Or "inner self">
passages.2:11: Discretion will watch over you; understanding will protect you,
passages.2:12: [in order] to deliver you from the way of evil,<note: Or "evildoer"> from a man who speaks devious things--
passages.2:13: those who forsake the paths of uprightness to walk in ways of darkness,
passages.2:14: those who are happy to do evil, [for] they delight in [the] deviousness of evil,
passages.2:15: {who are crooked in their ways},<note: Literally "that [in] their ways are crooked"> and devious in their paths;
passages.2:16: [in order] to deliver you from a strange woman, from a foreign woman [who] flatters<note: Or "makes smooth"> [with] her sayings,
passages.2:17: she who forsakes the partner of her youth and has forgotten the covenant of her God,
passages.2:18: for her house sinks to death, and to the dead<note: Or "Rephaim"> are her paths.
passages.2:19: [Of] all who go to her, none shall return, nor do they reach paths of life.
passages.2:20: So that you will walk on the road of those who are good, and the paths of those who are righteous you shall keep.
passages.2:21: For those who are upright will dwell [in the] land,<note: Or "earth"> and those who are blameless<note: Or "innocent"> will remain in it.
passages.2:22: And those who are wicked will be cut off from the land, and those who are treacherous will be uprooted from it.
passages.3:1: My child, do not forget my instruction, and may your heart guard my commands.
passages.3:2: For length of days, years of life, and peace they<note: That is, "my commands" (3:1)> shall add to you.
passages.3:3: May loyal love<note: Or "kindness, mercy"> and truth not forsake you; bind them around your neck, write them upon your heart.
passages.3:4: And you shall find favor and good sense<note: Or "understanding, prudence"> in the eyes of God and humankind.
passages.3:5: {Trust Yahweh}<note: Literally "trust toward Yahweh"> with all your heart; do not lean toward your own understanding.
passages.3:6: In all your ways acknowledge him, and he will straighten your paths.
passages.3:7: Do not be wise in your own eyes; fear Yahweh and retreat from evil.
passages.3:8: There shall be healing for your {flesh},<note: Literally "navel"> and refreshment for your body.
passages.3:9: Honor Yahweh from your substance,<note: Or "wealth, property"> and from the firstfruits of all that will come to you,
passages.3:10: and your barns shall be full of plenty, and your vats shall burst [with] new wine.
passages.3:11: Do not despise the discipline of Yahweh, my child. Do not be weary of his reproof
passages.3:12: because whomever Yahweh will love, he will rebuke, as a father delights in his son.
passages.3:13: Happy [is] {the one}<note: Literally "a man"> who finds wisdom, and one who obtains understanding.
passages.3:14: For her<note: Or "its"; both "wisdom" and "understanding" are feminine nouns and can be read as either "she" or "it"> income is better than the income of silver, and her revenue than [that of] gold.
passages.3:15: She is more precious than rubies, and all your desires shall not compare with her.
passages.3:16: Length of days [is] in her right hand; in her left hand [are] riches and honor.
passages.3:17: Her ways [are] ways of pleasantness, and all her paths [are] peace.
passages.3:18: She is a tree of life for those who seize her; those who take hold of her are considered happy.
passages.3:19: Yahweh in wisdom founded the earth; he established the heavens in understanding.
passages.3:20: With his knowledge, depths broke open, and clouds dropped dew.
passages.3:21: My child, may they<note: Grammatically, "they" most likely refers to clouds (3:20). In context, "they" may refer to wisdom and understanding (3:13).> not escape from your {sight};<note: Literally "eyes"> may you keep sound wisdom and prudence.
passages.3:22: They shall be life for your soul<note: Or "inner self"> and adornment<note: Or "favor"> for your neck.
passages.3:23: Then you will walk in the confidence of your ways, and your foot will not stumble.
passages.3:24: If you sit down, you will not panic,<note: Or "fear, dread"> and [if] you lie down, then your sleep shall be sweet.
passages.3:25: Do not be afraid of sudden panic,<note: Or "fear, dread"> or the storm of wickedness that will come.
passages.3:26: Yahweh will be {your confidence}<note: Literally "in your confidence"> and guard your foot from capture.
passages.3:27: Do not withhold good from its owner<note: Or "lord"> when it is in the power of your hand to do.
passages.3:28: Do not say to your neighbor, "Go and return and tomorrow I will give [it]," {when it is with you}.<note: Literally "and there is with you">
passages.3:29: Do not plot harm against your neighbor [who] dwells in confidence beside you.
passages.3:30: Do not quarrel with anyone without cause, when he did not do you harm.
passages.3:31: Do not envy a man of violence, and do not choose any of his ways,
passages.3:32: for he who is perverse [is] an abomination of Yahweh, but those who are upright [are] his confidence.
passages.3:33: The curse of Yahweh [is] on the house of the wicked, and the abode of the righteous ones he blesses.
passages.3:34: With those who scorn, he is scornful, but to those who are humble, he gives favor.
passages.3:35: They will inherit the honor of the wise, but stubborn fools, disgrace.
passages.4:1: Children, listen [to the] instruction of a father, and be attentive [in order] to know insight.
passages.4:2: For I have given you good instruction; do not forsake my teaching.
passages.4:3: When I was a son to my father, tender and alone before my mother,
passages.4:4: he taught me and said to me, "May your heart hold fast [to] my words; guard my commandments and live.
passages.4:5: Get wisdom and insight; do not forget and do not turn from the sayings of my mouth.
passages.4:6: Do not forsake her--then she will guard you; love her and she will keep you.
passages.4:7: The beginning of wisdom: Get wisdom! With all [that is in] your possession, gain insight.
passages.4:8: Cherish her and she will exalt you; she will honor you if you embrace her.
passages.4:9: She will give a garland for your head; she shall bestow a crown of glory upon you."
passages.4:10: Listen, my child, take my sayings, and [the] years of your life shall be great.
passages.4:11: In the way of wisdom I have instructed you; I have led you in the path of uprightness.
passages.4:12: {When you walk},<note: Literally "In your walking"> your step will not be hampered, and if you run, you will not stumble.
passages.4:13: Seize the instruction! Do not let go! Guard her, for she is your life.
passages.4:14: In the path of the wicked do not go; do not walk in the way of those who do evil.
passages.4:15: Avoid it; do not transgress it; turn away from it and pass by.
passages.4:16: For they will not sleep if they have not done wrong, and they are robbed of their sleep if they do not cause stumbling.
passages.4:17: For they ate the bread of wickedness, and they drank the wine of violence.
passages.4:18: But the path of the righteous ones [is] like the light of dawn, leading and shining until the day {is full}.<note: Literally "[is] correct">
passages.4:19: The way of the wicked ones [is] like deep darkness; they do not know what they stumble over.
passages.4:20: My child, be attentive to my words; to my sayings incline your ear.
passages.4:21: May they not escape from your {sight};<note: Literally "eyes"> keep them in [the] midst of your heart.
passages.4:22: For they are life to those who find them and healing {to the entire body}.<note: Literally "for all his flesh">
passages.4:23: With all vigilance, keep your heart, for from it [comes] the source<note: Or "extremity"> of life.
passages.4:24: Remove from yourself {deceitful speech},<note: Literally "crookedness of mouth"> and abolish {devious talk}<note: Literally "deviousness of lips"> from yourself.
passages.4:25: May your eyes look forward<note: Or "opposite"> and your gaze be straight before you.
passages.4:26: May the path of your foot be balanced and all your ways be sure.
passages.4:27: Do not swerve right or left; remove your foot from evil.
passages.5:1: My child, be attentive to my wisdom, and to my understanding incline your ear;
passages.5:2: [in order] to keep prudence, and knowledge will guard your lips.
passages.5:3: For the lips of the strange woman will drip honey, and smoother than oil is her mouth.<note: Or "palate">
passages.5:4: But her end is bitter as the wormwood, sharp as a two-edged sword.
passages.5:5: Her feet go down [to] death; her steps take hold [of] Sheol.<note: A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld>
passages.5:6: She does not observe<note: Or "examine, weigh"> the path of life; her ways wander, [and] she does not know [it].
passages.5:7: Now, O children, listen to me; do not depart from the sayings of my mouth.
passages.5:8: Keep your paths far from her, and do not go near to the door of her house,
passages.5:9: lest you give your honor to the others, and your years to the merciless,
passages.5:10: lest strangers take [their] fill of your strength, and your labors [go] to the house of a foreigner,
passages.5:11: and you groan at your end, when your flesh and body are consumed,
passages.5:12: and say "How I hated discipline, and I despised reproof!"
passages.5:13: and "I did not listen to the voice of my teachers, and I did not incline my ear to my instructors!
passages.5:14: I was almost at utter<note: Or "all, every, whole"> ruin<note: Or "evil"> in the midst of the assembly and congregation."
passages.5:15: Drink water from your [own] cistern and flowing waters from inside your own well.
passages.5:16: Shall your springs be scattered outward? In the streets, [shall there be] streams of water?
passages.5:17: May they be yours alone, and not for strangers [who are] with you.
passages.5:18: May your fountain be blessed, and rejoice in the wife<note: Or "woman"> of your youth.
passages.5:19: [She is] a deer of love and a doe of grace; may her breasts satisfy you {always};<note: Literally "at all time"> by her love may you be intoxicated continually.
passages.5:20: Why should you be intoxicated, my child, by a strange woman, and embrace the bosom of a foreigner?
passages.5:21: For before the eyes of Yahweh [are] {human ways},<note: Literally "the ways of man/humankind"> and all his paths he examines.
passages.5:22: His iniquities shall ensnare him, the evildoer, and in the vanity of his sin he shall be caught.
passages.5:23: He shall die {for lack of}<note: Literally "with there is no"> discipline, and in the greatness of his folly he shall be lost.
passages.6:1: My child, if you have pledged to your neighbor, [if] you have bound {yourself}<note: Literally "palms of your hands"> to the stranger,
passages.6:2: [if] you are snared by the sayings of your mouth, [if] you are caught by the sayings of your mouth,
passages.6:3: do this, then, my child, and save yourself, for you have come into {the palm of your neighbor's hand}:<note: Literally "the palm of the hand of your neighbor"> Go, humble yourself, plead with your neighbor.
passages.6:4: Do not give sleep to your eyes, or slumber to your eyelids.
passages.6:5: Save yourself like a gazelle from a hand, or like a bird from the hand of a fowler.
passages.6:6: Go to the ant, lazy! Consider its ways and be wise.
passages.6:7: It has no chief, officer, or ruler.
passages.6:8: In the summer, it prepares its food; in the harvest, it gathers its sustenance.
passages.6:9: How long will you lie down, lazy? When will you rise up from your sleep?
passages.6:10: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands for rest--
passages.6:11: like a {robber}<note: Literally "one who walks," that is, a vagabond> shall your poverty come, and what you lack like an armed man.
passages.6:12: A worthless man, an evil man, goes around with {deceitful speech}.<note: Literally "crookedness of mouth">
passages.6:13: Winking in his eye, shuffling in his foot, pointing in his fingers,
passages.6:14: perversion in his heart, he devises evil; at all times he will send out discord.<note: Or "quarrels">
passages.6:15: Upon {such a man},<note: Literally "thus"> suddenly shall his calamity come; in a moment he will be damaged and there is no healing.<note: Or "repair">
passages.6:16: There are six [things] Yahweh hates, and seven [things are] abominations of his soul:<note: Or "inner self">
passages.6:17: haughty eyes, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood,
passages.6:18: a devising heart, plans of deception, feet that hurry to run to evil,<note: Hebrew "the evil">
passages.6:19: a false witness who breathes lies and sends out discord<note: Or "quarrels"> between brothers.
passages.6:20: My child, keep [the] commandment of your father, and do not disregard [the] instruction of your mother.
passages.6:21: Bind them on your heart continually; tie them upon your neck.
passages.6:22: {When you walk},<note: Literally "In your walking"> she<note: That is, "commandment" and "instruction"> will lead you, {When you lie down},<note: Literally "In your lying down"> she will watch over you, and [when] you awake, she will converse [with] you.
passages.6:23: For [like] a lamp [is] a commandment, and instruction [is] light, and the way of life<note: Hebrew "lives"> [is the] reproof of discipline,
passages.6:24: [in order] to preserve you from an evil woman,<note: Or "wife"> from the smoothness of [the] tongue of {an adulteress}.<note: Literally "a foreign woman">
passages.6:25: Do not desire her beauty in your heart; may she not capture you with her eyelashes.
passages.6:26: For [the] price of a woman, a prostitute,<note: Or "whore"> [is the] price of a loaf of bread, but the {woman belonging to a man}<note: Literally "the woman of a man"> hunts precious life.
passages.6:27: Can a man carry fire in his lap, and his clothes not burn?
passages.6:28: If a man walks upon the hot coals, will his feet not be burned?
passages.6:29: Thus, he who goes to the wife of his neighbor, any who touches her shall not go unpunished.
passages.6:30: [People] do not despise a thief when he steals to fill himself<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> when he is hungry.
passages.6:31: But [if] he is found, he will pay sevenfold, every possession of his house he shall give.
passages.6:32: He who commits adultery [with] a woman lacks {sense},<note: Literally "heart"> he destroys himself<note: Or "his soul," or "his life"> who does it.
passages.6:33: A wound and dishonor he will find, and his disgrace will not be wiped out.
passages.6:34: For jealousy [is the] fury of a husband, and he will not show restraint on the day of revenge.
passages.6:35: He will not accept {any compensation},<note: Literally "[the] face of any compensation"> and he will not be willing, though the bribe is large.
passages.7:1: My child, guard my sayings; store my commandments with you.
passages.7:2: Keep my commands and live, and my teaching like [the] {apple of your eye}.<note: A single word meaning "pupil of the eye">
passages.7:3: Bind them on your fingers; write them on the tablet of your heart.
passages.7:4: Say to wisdom,<note: Hebrew "the wisdom"> "you are my sister," and you shall call insight,<note: Hebrew "the insight"> "{intimate friend}."<note: Literally "one who is known." To "know" is often a euphemism for intercourse. Therefore "intimate friend" may also be read "lover.">
passages.7:5: [In order] to guard yourself from {an adulteress},<note: Literally "a strange woman"> from the foreigner who {makes her words smooth}.<note: Literally "causes to be smooth her words">
passages.7:6: For at the window of my house, through my lattice, I looked down.
passages.7:7: And I saw among the simple, I observed among the youth, a young man lacking {sense},<note: Literally "heart">
passages.7:8: passing on the street {at}<note: Literally "at the place of"> her corner, and he takes the road [to] her house,
passages.7:9: at twilight, at [the] day's evening, in [the] midst of night and the darkness.
passages.7:10: Then behold! A woman [comes] to meet him [with the] garment of a prostitute<note: Or "whore"> and {a secret heart}.<note: Literally "secret of heart">
passages.7:11: She is loud and stubborn; her feet do not stay at her house.
passages.7:12: Now in the street, now in the square, {at}<note: Literally "at the place of"> every corner she lies in wait.
passages.7:13: She took hold of <note: Or "strengthened"> him and kissed him. Her face was impudent, and she said to him,
passages.7:14: "Sacrifices of peace offerings [are] upon me; {today}<note: Literally "the day"> I completed my vows.
passages.7:15: So<note: Hebrew "thus"> I have come out to meet you, to seek your face, and I have found you.
passages.7:16: [With] coverings I have adorned my couch, spreads of the linen of Egypt;
passages.7:17: I have perfumed my bed [with] myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
passages.7:18: Come, let us take [our] fill of love making, until the morning let us delight in love.
passages.7:19: For there is no man<note: Or "husband"> in his home; he has gone on a {long journey}.<note: Literally "a journey from far">
passages.7:20: The bag of money he took in his hand, for [on] the day of the full moon he will come home."
passages.7:21: She persuades him with the greatness of her teachings; with her smooth lips she compels him.
passages.7:22: He goes after her suddenly; like an ox to the slaughter he goes, and like a stag to the instruction of a fool,
passages.7:23: until an arrow pierces his {entrails},<note: Literally "heaviness," often referring to the liver> like a bird rushing into a snare, but he does not know that {it will cost him his life}.<note: Literally "it is against his life">
passages.7:24: And now, my children, listen to me, and be attentive to the sayings of my mouth.
passages.7:25: May your heart not turn aside to her ways; do not stray into her path.
passages.7:26: For many slain she has laid low, and countless<note: Or "strong men"> [are] all of her killings.
passages.7:27: The ways of Sheol<note: A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld> [are] her house, descending to chambers of death.
passages.8:1: Does not wisdom call, and understanding raise its voice?
passages.8:2: {Atop the heights}<note: Literally "At a head of the heights"> beside the road, at the crossroads she stands.
passages.8:3: Beside gates, before towns, [at the] entrance of doors, she cries out:
passages.8:4: "To you, O {people},<note: Literally "men"> I call, and my cry is to the children of humankind.
passages.8:5: Learn prudence, O simple ones; fools, learn {intelligence}.<note: Literally "heart">
passages.8:6: Listen! For noble things I will speak, and upright things from the opening of my lips.
passages.8:7: My mouth will utter truth, and wickedness [is] an abomination to my lips.
passages.8:8: All sayings of my mouth [are] in righteousness; none of them are twisted and crooked.
passages.8:9: All of them are straight to him who understands, and upright to those who find knowledge.
passages.8:10: Take my teaching and not silver; may you choose knowledge rather than choice gold.
passages.8:11: For wisdom is better than jewels, and all desires shall not compare with her.
passages.8:12: I, wisdom, live with prudence, and I find knowledge and discretion.
passages.8:13: The fear of Yahweh [is] hatred of evil, pride, and arrogance and an evil way. And I hate a mouth of perversity.
passages.8:14: {Advice and sound judgment}<note: Literally "To/for me are advice and sound judgment"> are mine; I am understanding, {strength is mine}.<note: Literally "to/for me is strength">
passages.8:15: By me kings reign, and rulers decree righteousness.
passages.8:16: By me rulers rule, and nobles--all judges of righteousness.
passages.8:17: I love {those who love me},<note: Literally "her lovers"> and those who seek me diligently shall find me.
passages.8:18: Fortune and glory [are] with me, enduring wealth and righteousness.
passages.8:19: My fruit is better than gold,<note: Literally "fine gold"> even refined gold, and my yield than choice silver.
passages.8:20: In the way of righteousness I walk, in the midst of paths of justice,
passages.8:21: [in order] to endow those who love me [with] wealth, and I will fill their treasuries.
passages.8:22: "Yahweh possessed<note: Or "gained," or "acquired"> me, [the] first of his ways, before his acts {of old}.<note: Literally "from before" or "from then">
passages.8:23: From eternity, I was set up from [the] first, from the beginning<note: Hebrew "beginnings"> of the earth.
passages.8:24: When there were no depths, I was brought forth, when there were no springs of {abounding}<note: Literally "made heavy"> water.
passages.8:25: Before mountains had been shaped, before hills, I was brought forth.
passages.8:26: When he had not yet made earth and fields, or the first dust of the world,
passages.8:27: {when he established}<note: Literally "in his establishing"> the heavens, there I [was], {when he drew}<note: Literally "in his drawing"> a circle upon the face of the deep,
passages.8:28: {when he made}<note: Literally "in his making"> skies from above, when he founded fountains of the deep,
passages.8:29: {when he assigned}<note: Literally "in his assigning"> his limits to the sea, that waters shall not transgress his {command},<note: Literally "mouth"> {when he marked}<note: Literally "in his marking"> the foundations of the earth,
passages.8:30: I was {beside}<note: Literally "at the place of"> him, a master workman, and I was delighting day by day, rejoicing before him {always},<note: Literally "in all [of] time">
passages.8:31: rejoicing in the world of his earth, and my delight [was] with the children of humankind.
passages.8:32: "And now, children, listen to me; happy [are] those who will keep my ways.
passages.8:33: Hear teaching and be wise; do not neglect [it].
passages.8:34: Happy [is the] person who listens to me, [in order] to keep watch at my doors day by day, [in order] to guard the frames of my entrances.
passages.8:35: For he who finds me [is] he who finds<note: Hebrew "those who find"> life, and he obtains favor from Yahweh.
passages.8:36: But he who misses me injures himself.<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> All those who hate me love death."
passages.9:1: Wisdom has built her house; she has hewn her seven pillars.
passages.9:2: She has slaughtered her slaughtering, mixed her wine, [and] also set her table.
passages.9:3: She has sent her servant girls,<note: Or "young maidens"> she calls upon the wings of the high places of town,
passages.9:4: "Whoever [is] simple, let him turn here." As for the one who lacks {sense},<note: Literally "heart"> she says to him,
passages.9:5: "Come, eat with my bread; drink with the wine I have mixed.
passages.9:6: Lay aside simplicity and live; walk in the way of understanding."
passages.9:7: He who corrects a scoffer gains abuse for himself, and he who rebukes the wicked {gets hurt}.<note: Literally "abuse him">
passages.9:8: Do not rebuke a scoffer, lest he hate you; rebuke the wise and he will love you.
passages.9:9: Give to a wise one and he will become more wise; {teach}<note: Literally "make known to"> a righteous one and he will increase learning.
passages.9:10: The start of wisdom is fear of Yahweh, and knowledge of the Holy One,<note: Or "holy ones"> insight.
passages.9:11: For by me your days shall increase, and years of life shall multiply for you.
passages.9:12: If you are wise, you are wise for yourself, and [if] you scoff, alone you shall bear [it].
passages.9:13: A woman of foolishness is loud, simple, and does not know {it}.<note: Literally "what">
passages.9:14: She sits at the door of her house, upon a throne [at the] high places of town,
passages.9:15: [in order] to call to those who pass by the road, those who go straight [on] their way:
passages.9:16: "Whoever is simple, may he turn here!" As for he who lacks {sense},<note: Literally "heart"> she says to him,
passages.9:17: "Stolen waters are sweet, and bread of secrecy is pleasant."
passages.9:18: But he does not know that the dead<note: Or "Rephaim"> [are] there, in the depths of Sheol<note: A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld> [are] her guests.
passages.10:1: The proverbs of Solomon: A wise child makes a father glad, but a foolish child grieves his mother.
passages.10:2: Treasures of wickedness do not profit, but righteousness delivers from death.
passages.10:3: Yahweh will not cause a righteous person<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> to go hungry, but the craving of the wicked he will thwart.
passages.10:4: A slack hand causes poverty, but the hand of the diligent enriches.
passages.10:5: He who gathers in the summer [is] a child who is prudent; he who sleeps at the harvest [is] a child who brings shame.
passages.10:6: Blessings [belong] to the head of the righteous, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
passages.10:7: The memory of righteousness [is] like a blessing, but the name of the wicked will rot.
passages.10:8: A heart of wisdom will heed commandments, but a babbling fool will come to ruin.
passages.10:9: Whoever walks in integrity<note: Hebrew "in the integrity"> will walk securely, but whoever follows perversity, his ways will be made known.
passages.10:10: The winking of an eye causes<note: Or "gives, sets up"> trouble, and the foolishness of lips comes to ruin.
passages.10:11: A fountain of life [is] a mouth of righteousness, and a mouth of wickedness conceals violence.
passages.10:12: Hatred stirs up strife, but love covers over all offenses.
passages.10:13: On the lips of one who has understanding, wisdom is found, but a rod [is] for the back of one who lacks {sense}.<note: Literally "heart">
passages.10:14: Those who are wise lay up knowledge, but [to] the mouth of the fool, ruin draws near.
passages.10:15: The wealth of the rich [is] the city of his strength; the ruin of the poor [is] their poverty.
passages.10:16: The wage of the righteous [leads] to life; the gain of the wicked to sin.
passages.10:17: [On] the path to life is he who guards instruction, but he who rejects rebuke goes astray.
passages.10:18: He who conceals hatred [has] lips of deceit, and he who utters slander--he is a fool.
passages.10:19: In many words, transgression is not lacking, but he who restrains his lips is prudent.
passages.10:20: Choice silver is a tongue of righteousness, a heart<note: Or "mind"> of wickedness is {of little worth}.<note: Literally "like a little">
passages.10:21: Lips of righteousness feed many, but fools {die for lack of sense}.<note: Literally "in the lack of heart, they die">
passages.10:22: The blessing of Yahweh makes [one] rich, and he does not increase sorrow with it.
passages.10:23: [It is] like a sport for a fool to do wrong, wisdom for a person of understanding.
passages.10:24: The dread of the wicked will come upon him, but the desire of the righteous will be granted.
passages.10:25: With the passing of the tempest, there is no wickedness, but [the] righteous have a foundation forever.
passages.10:26: Like vinegar to the tooth and like smoke to the eyes, thus [is] the lazy to one who employs<note: Or "sends"> him.
passages.10:27: The fear of Yahweh adds life, but the years of the wicked are shortened.
passages.10:28: The hope of the righteous [is] gladness, but the expectation of the wicked comes to nothing.
passages.10:29: A stronghold for the upright is the way of Yahweh, but ruin [belongs] to {evildoers}.<note: Literally "them who do evil">
passages.10:30: The righteous one is forever; he will not be removed. But the wicked will not remain in the land.<note: Or "earth">
passages.10:31: The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but a tongue of perversity will be cut off.
passages.10:32: The lips of the righteous know [the] acceptable, but the mouth of the wicked, the perverse.
passages.11:1: Balances of deceit [are] an abomination of Yahweh, but {an accurate weight}<note: Literally "a full stone" or "a pure stone"> delights him.
passages.11:2: Pride comes, then disgrace comes, but wisdom [is] with the humble.
passages.11:3: The integrity of the upright guides them, but the crookedness of the treacherous destroys them.
passages.11:4: Wealth does not profit on the day of wrath, but righteousness will deliver from death.
passages.11:5: The righteousness of the blameless will keep his ways straight, but the wicked will fall by his wickedness.
passages.11:6: The righteousness of the upright will save them, but by a scheme the treacherous will be taken captive.
passages.11:7: With the death of a wicked person, hope will die, and the expectation of the godless perishes.
passages.11:8: The righteous is delivered from trouble, but the wicked enters into it.
passages.11:9: With a mouth, the godless shall destroy his neighbor, but by knowledge the righteous are delivered.
passages.11:10: When good [is with] the righteous, [the] city rejoices, and with the perishing of the wicked, jubilation.
passages.11:11: By the blessing of the upright, a city will be exalted, but by the mouth of the wicked, it will be overthrown.
passages.11:12: He who lacks {sense}<note: Literally "heart"> belittles his neighbor, but a person of intelligence will remain silent.
passages.11:13: A gossip walks [about] telling a secret, but the trustworthy in spirit keeps [the] matter.
passages.11:14: Where there is no guidance, a nation<note: Or "people"> shall fall, but [there is] safety in an abundance of counsel.
passages.11:15: He will suffer trouble when he loans to a stranger, but he who refuses a pledge is safe.
passages.11:16: A woman of grace receives honor, but the ruthless gets wealth.
passages.11:17: A person of kindness rewards himself,<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> but a cruel [person] harms his own flesh.
passages.11:18: The wicked earns<note: Or "does, makes"> {deceptive gain},<note: Literally "gain of deception"> but he who sows righteousness, a {true reward}.<note: Literally "a reward of truth">
passages.11:19: He who is steadfast in righteousness [is] to life as<note: Hebrew "and"> he who pursues evil [is] to death.
passages.11:20: An abomination of Yahweh [are] the {crooked of heart},<note: Literally "crooked ones of heart"; "heart" may also be translated "mind"> but his delight [are] {those with blameless ways}.<note: Literally "blameless ones of ways">
passages.11:21: {Rest assured},<note: Literally "Hand to hand"> the wicked will not go unpunished, but the offspring<note: Or "seed"> of the righteous will escape.
passages.11:22: A ring of gold in [the] snout of a pig [is] a woman [who is] beautiful but without discretion.
passages.11:23: The desire of the righteous [is] only good, but the expectation of the wicked, wrath.
passages.11:24: There is one who gives yet {grows richer},<note: Literally "adding more"> but he who withholds {what is right}<note: Literally "from what is right"> only [finds] need.
passages.11:25: A person of blessing will be enriched, and he who gives water also will be refreshed.
passages.11:26: He who withholds grain, the people curse him, but a blessing [is] for the head of him who sells.
passages.11:27: He who diligently seeks good seeks favor, but he who inquires of evil, it will come to him.
passages.11:28: He who trusts in his wealth [is] he who will fall, but like a green leaf the righteous will flourish.
passages.11:29: He who brings trouble [to] his household, he will inherit wind,<note: Or "breath, spirit"> and a fool will serve the wise of heart.
passages.11:30: The fruit of righteousness is a tree of life, and he who captures souls<note: Or "persons," or "inner selves"> [is] wise.
passages.11:31: If the righteous on earth will be repaid, {how much more}<note: Literally "more for"> the wicked and sinner.
passages.12:1: He who loves discipline loves knowledge, but he who hates rebuke [is] stupid.
passages.12:2: The good obtains favor from Yahweh, but anyone who schemes, he condemns.
passages.12:3: A person will not be established by wickedness, but the root of the righteous will not be moved.
passages.12:4: A woman of strength<note: Or "honor"> [is] the crown of her master,<note: Or "lord, owner"> but like rot in his bones is she who brings shame.
passages.12:5: The thoughts of the righteous are<note: Hebrew "is"> just; the advice of the wicked is treacherous.
passages.12:6: The words of the wicked [are] an ambush of blood, but the mouth of the upright delivers them.
passages.12:7: The wicked are overthrown and {are no more},<note: Literally "there is no them"> but the house of the righteous shall stand.
passages.12:8: For his mouth of good sense, a man will be recommended, but he who is of perverse {mind}<note: Literally "heart"> will be despised.
passages.12:9: It is better to be lowly and a servant {to someone}<note: Literally "for him," "[belonging] to him"> than self-glorifying and lacking food.
passages.12:10: The righteous knows the life<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> of his animal, but the compassion<note: Hebrew "compassions"> of the wicked is cruel.
passages.12:11: He who works his land will have plenty of food, but he who follows worthless things lacks {sense}.<note: Literally "heart">
passages.12:12: The wicked covets the proceeds of evil, but the root of the righteous {bears fruit}.<note: Literally "gives, sets up">
passages.12:13: By the transgression of lips, evil is ensnared, but the righteous escapes from trouble.
passages.12:14: From the fruit of the mouth of a man, he is filled with good, and the reward of {a man's labor}<note: Literally "the hands of a man"> will return to him.
passages.12:15: The way of a fool is upright in his [own] eyes, but he who listens to advice [is] wise.
passages.12:16: As for a fool, {on that very day}<note: Literally "on the day"> he makes his anger known, but he who ignores an insult [is] prudent.
passages.12:17: He who will speak truth will reveal righteousness, but the witness of falsehood, deceit.
passages.12:18: There is one who speaks rashly, like the thrust of a sword, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
passages.12:19: A lip of truth endures forever, but a tongue of deception lasts only a moment.
passages.12:20: Deceit [is] in the heart<note: Or "mind"> of {those who plan}<note: Literally "the planners of"> evil, but to {those who plan}<note: Literally "the planners of"> peace, [there is] joy.
passages.12:21: {No evil will happen}<note: Literally "All evil will not happen"> to the righteous, but the wicked are filled [with] trouble.
passages.12:22: An abomination of Yahweh are lips of deceit, but they who act faithfully [are] his delight.
passages.12:23: A clever person conceals knowledge, but the heart<note: Or "mind"> of a fool<note: Hebrew "fools"> announces folly.
passages.12:24: The hand of the diligent ones will rule, but the lazy will belong to forced labor.
passages.12:25: Anxiety in the heart<note: Or "mind"> of a man will weigh him down, but a good word will cheer him.
passages.12:26: A righteous person will seek out his neighbor, but the way of the wicked will lead them astray.
passages.12:27: The lazy will not roast his game, but diligence is the precious wealth of a man.
passages.12:28: On the road of righteousness is life, and [on] the way of the path, [may there be] no death.
passages.13:1: A wise child [hears] the discipline of a father, but a scoffer does not listen to a rebuke.
passages.13:2: From the fruit of the mouth of a man, he shall eat what is good, but the desire<note: Or "soul"> of the treacherous, wrongdoing.
passages.13:3: He who keeps his mouth guards his life;<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> he who opens his lips, ruin [belongs] to him.
passages.13:4: The soul<note: Or "life"> of the lazy craves, but there is nothing, but the person of diligence is richly supplied.
passages.13:5: The righteous hates a word of falsehood; the wicked will bring shame and {disgrace}.<note: Literally "he will bring disgrace">
passages.13:6: Righteousness will guard the upright of way, but wickedness will overthrow sin.
passages.13:7: There is one who acts rich but {has nothing};<note: Literally "there is no"> another who pretends to be poor but [has] wealth.
passages.13:8: The ransom of the life of a man [is] his wealth, but the poor does not receive a threat.
passages.13:9: The light of the righteous will rejoice, but the lamp of the wicked will die out.
passages.13:10: Only by insolence is strife set up, and wisdom [is] with those who take advice.
passages.13:11: Wealth [gained] from haste<note: Or "vanity"> will dwindle, but he who gathers {little by little}<note: Literally "upon the hand"> will increase it.
passages.13:12: Hope that is deferred makes the heart<note: Or "mind"> sick, but a desire fulfilled [is] a tree of life.
passages.13:13: He who despises a word will bring destruction on himself, but he who respects a commandment will be rewarded.
passages.13:14: The teaching of the wise [is] a fountain of life, [in order] to avoid the snares of death.
passages.13:15: Good sense grants favor, but the way of the faithless is coarse.
passages.13:16: Anyone who is clever will act with intelligence, but the fool will display folly.
passages.13:17: A messenger of wickedness will fall into trouble, but an envoy of the faithful [brings] healing.
passages.13:18: Poverty and disgrace [belong to] him who ignores instruction, but he who guards reproof will be honored.
passages.13:19: A desire {fulfilled}<note: Literally "made to be," "brought about"> will be sweet to the soul, but an abomination of fools is turning from evil.
passages.13:20: Walk with the wise and be wise, but as for the companion of fools, he will suffer harm.
passages.13:21: Misfortune will pursue sinners, but the righteous {will be rewarded with prosperity}.<note: Literally "it will reward prosperity">
passages.13:22: He who is good will leave an inheritance to {his grandchildren},<note: Literally "sons of sons"> and stored up for the righteous [is] the wealth of a sinner.
passages.13:23: [There is] much food [in] the field of the poor, but {it is swept away}<note: Literally "there is sweeping away"> by {injustice}.<note: Literally "no justice">
passages.13:24: He who withholds his rod hates his child, but he who loves him {gives him}<note: Literally "visits him"> discipline.
passages.13:25: The righteous eats to satisfy his life,<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> but the belly of the wicked will lack.
passages.14:1: The {wisest of women}<note: Literally "wise ones of women"> builds her house, but the foolish tears it down with her hands.
passages.14:2: He who walks in uprightness fears Yahweh, but he who is devious [in] his ways displeases him.
passages.14:3: In the mouth of a fool is the rod of pride, but the lips of the wise preserve them.
passages.14:4: {When there are no}<note: Literally "In there is no"> oxen the manger is empty, but an abundance of crops [comes] by the strength of an ox.<note: Hebrew "bull">
passages.14:5: A faithful witness does not lie, but he who breathes out falsehood is a witness of deceit.
passages.14:6: A scoffer seeks wisdom, but there is none, but knowledge {comes easily to him who understands}.<note: Literally "to one who understands it comes easy">
passages.14:7: Leave {the presence of a foolish man},<note: Literally "from the presence [belonging] to a man of foolishness"> [for] you will not [come to] know {words of knowledge}.<note: Literally "lips of knowledge">
passages.14:8: The wisdom of the clever is understanding his ways, but the folly of fools is deceit.
passages.14:9: Fools mock<note: Hebrew "he mocks"> [the] guilt offering, but among the upright, it is favorable.
passages.14:10: The heart<note: Or "mind"> knows the bitterness of its soul,<note: Or "life," or "inner self"> but in its joy, it will not share itself with a stranger.
passages.14:11: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, but the tent of the upright will flourish.
passages.14:12: There is a way [that seems] upright {to}<note: Literally "to the face of"> a man, but its end [is] the way of death.
passages.14:13: Even in laughter, a heart may be sad, and the end of joy [may be] grief.
passages.14:14: From his ways, the perverse of heart will be satisfied, and {from his own},<note: Literally "from upon him"> [so shall] a good man.
passages.14:15: The simple will believe every word, but the clever will consider his step.
passages.14:16: The wise is cautious and turns from evil, but the fool throws off restraint and is confident.
passages.14:17: He who is short of {temper}<note: Literally "nostril"> will act foolishly, and the man who schemes will be hated.
passages.14:18: The simple are adorned [with] folly, but the clever are crowned with knowledge.
passages.14:19: The evil bow down before the good, and the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
passages.14:20: The poor is disliked even by his neighbor, but the lovers of the rich are many.
passages.14:21: He who despises his neighbor is a sinner, but he who has mercy on the poor blesses him.
passages.14:22: Have they not erred, those who plan evil? But loyalty and faithfulness [belong to] those who plan good.
passages.14:23: In all toil, there is profit, but the {talk}<note: Literally "word, matter, thing"> of lips [leads] only to poverty.
passages.14:24: The crown of the wise [is] their wealth; the folly of fools is folly.
passages.14:25: He who saves lives<note: Or "souls," or "inner selves"> [is] a witness of truth, but he who utters lies [is] a betrayer.
passages.14:26: In the fear of Yahweh, there is confidence of strength, and for his children, there will be refuge.
passages.14:27: The fear of Yahweh [is] a fountain of life, [in order] to turn from the snares of death.
passages.14:28: In the multitude of people is the glory of the king, but without a population, a prince [is] ruined.
passages.14:29: [He who is] slow to anger [has] great understanding, but the hasty of spirit<note: Or "breath"> exalts folly.
passages.14:30: A heart<note: Or "mind"> of tranquility<note: Or "he who heals"> [is] life [to the] flesh, but causes bones of passion to rot.
passages.14:31: He who oppresses the poor insults him who made him, but he who has mercy on the poor honors him.
passages.14:32: By his evildoing, the wicked will be overthrown, and the righteous will find refuge in his death.
passages.14:33: In the heart<note: Or "mind"> of him who has understanding, wisdom rests, but [even] in the midst of fools it becomes known.
passages.14:34: Righteousness will exalt a nation, but sin [is] a reproach to a people.
passages.14:35: The favor of a king [is] for the servant who deals wisely, but his wrath will be [on] him who acts shamefully.
passages.15:1: A soft answer will turn away wrath, but a word of trouble will stir {anger}.<note: Literally "nostril">
passages.15:2: The tongue of the wise will dispense knowledge, but the mouth of fools will pour out folly.
passages.15:3: In every place, the eyes of Yahweh keep watch over the evil and the good.
passages.15:4: Gentleness<note: Or "Healing"> of tongue is a tree of life, but perverseness in it<note: That is, the tongue> [causes] a break in spirit.
passages.15:5: A fool will despise the instruction of his father, but he who guards reproof is prudent.
passages.15:6: [In] the house of the righteous [there is] much treasure, but the income of the wicked brings trouble.
passages.15:7: The lips of the wise will spread knowledge, but the heart<note: Or "mind"> of fools, not so.
passages.15:8: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination of Yahweh, but the prayer of the upright [is] his delight.
passages.15:9: An abomination of Yahweh is the way of the wicked, but he who pursues righteousness he will love.
passages.15:10: Severe discipline [belongs] to him who forsakes the way; he who hates a rebuke will die.
passages.15:11: Sheol<note: A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld> and Abaddon<note: Poetic synonym for "Sheol." Only mentioned in the ot in relation to Sheol, the grave, or death.> [are] before Yahweh, {how much more}<note: Literally "more for"> the hearts of the children of men!
passages.15:12: A scoffer does not like {his rebuke};<note: Literally "rebuke [belonging] to him"> to the wise he will not go.
passages.15:13: A heart<note: Or "mind"> of gladness will make good {countenance},<note: Literally "faces"> but in sorrow of heart<note: Or "mind"> a spirit is broken.
passages.15:14: The heart of him who understands will seek knowledge, but the faces of fools, they<note: Hebrew "he/it"> will feed on folly.
passages.15:15: All the days of the poor [are] hard, but goodness of heart<note: Or "mind"> [is] a continuous feast.
passages.15:16: Better [is] little with the fear of Yahweh than great treasure and trouble with it.<note: Or "him">
passages.15:17: Better [is] a dinner of vegetables when<note: Hebrew "and"> love [is] there than a fattened ox and hatred with it.<note: Or "him">
passages.15:18: A man who is hot-tempered will stir up strife, but he who is slow [to] {anger},<note: Literally "nostrils"> he will calm contention.
passages.15:19: The way of the lazy is like a hedge of thorns,<note: Hebrew "thorn"> but the path of the upright [is] a highway.
passages.15:20: A child of wisdom will make a father glad, but a {foolish person},<note: Literally "foolishness of humankind"> he despises his mother.
passages.15:21: Folly is a joy to him who lacks {sense},<note: Literally "heart"> and a person of understanding {will walk upright}.<note: Literally "he will walk upright walking">
passages.15:22: Plans go wrong when there is no counsel, but with many advisors it will succeed.
passages.15:23: Joy [belongs] to a man with answers in his mouth, and a word in its time, how good [it is]!
passages.15:24: The path of life [leads] upward for him who has insight, in order to turn away from Sheol below.
passages.15:25: The house of the proud, Yahweh will tear [it] down, but he will maintain the {property line}<note: Literally "boundary"> of the widow.
passages.15:26: Plans of evil [are] an abomination of Yahweh, but gracious words are pure.
passages.15:27: He who makes trouble for his house [is] he who is greedy for unjust gain, but he who hates bribes will live.
passages.15:28: A heart<note: Or "mind"> of righteousness will ponder the answer, but a mouth of wickedness will pour out deceit.
passages.15:29: Yahweh is far from the wicked, but the prayers of the righteous he will hear.
passages.15:30: From the light of the eyes, the heart<note: Or "mind"> will rejoice, and good news will enliven the bones.<note: Hebrew "bone">
passages.15:31: The ear of him who listens [to] admonitions of life, in the midst of the wise it will lodge.
passages.15:32: He who ignores instruction despises himself,<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> but he who hears admonition gains heart.<note: Or "mind">
passages.15:33: Fear of Yahweh [is] the instruction of the wise, and before honor [comes] humility.
passages.16:1: To mortals [belong] the plans of the heart, but from Yahweh [comes] the answer of the tongue.
passages.16:2: All the ways of a man [are] pure in his own eyes, but Yahweh weighs the spirit.<note: Or "breath">
passages.16:3: Commit your work to Yahweh, and your plans will be established.
passages.16:4: All Yahweh has made [is] for his<note: Or "its"> purpose, and even the wicked for the day of trouble.
passages.16:5: An abomination of Yahweh [are] all who are arrogant of heart;<note: Or "mind"> {rest assured},<note: Literally "hand to hand"> he will not go unpunished.
passages.16:6: By loyalty and faithfulness, iniquity will be covered over,<note: Or "atoned for"> and by fear of Yahweh {one turns}<note: Literally "turning"> from evil.
passages.16:7: When the ways of a man are pleasing [to] Yahweh, even his enemies he will cause to make peace with him.
passages.16:8: Better is little with righteousness than great income with no justice.
passages.16:9: The {mind}<note: Literally "heart"> of a person will plan his ways, and Yahweh will direct his steps.
passages.16:10: A decision is upon the lips of a king; in judgment his mouth will not sin.
passages.16:11: A balance and scales of justice [belong] to Yahweh; all the weights of the bag [are] his work.
passages.16:12: An abomination to kings [is] doing evil, for by righteousness the throne will be established.
passages.16:13: The delight of kings [are] the lips of righteousness, and he who speaks what is upright he will love.
passages.16:14: The wrath of a king [is] a messenger of death, but one who is wise will appease<note: Or "atone, cover over"> it.
passages.16:15: In the light of the face of the king [there is] life, and his favor [is] like a cloud of spring rain.
passages.16:16: Getting wisdom: {how much}<note: Literally "what"> better than gold! And getting understanding: it is chosen {over}<note: Literally "from"> silver.
passages.16:17: The highway of the upright, it turns from evil, he who guards himself<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> keeps his way.
passages.16:18: Before destruction [comes] pride, and before a fall, a haughty spirit.<note: Hebrew "a haughty of spirit">
passages.16:19: Better a lowly spirit with the poor than dividing the spoil with the proud.
passages.16:20: He who is attentive to a matter will find goodness, and he who trusts in Yahweh, his own happiness.
passages.16:21: The wise of heart<note: Or "mind"> is called perceptive, but he who is pleasant of lips will increase persuasiveness.
passages.16:22: A fountain of life is wisdom for its owner,<note: Or "master"> but the instruction<note: Or "punishment"> of fools is folly.
passages.16:23: The heart<note: Or "mind"> of the wise will make his mouth judicious, and upon his lips, it<note: Or "he"> will add persuasiveness.
passages.16:24: Pleasant sayings [are] a honeycomb, sweetness to the soul and healing to the bones.
passages.16:25: There is a way [that seems] upright {to}<note: Literally "to the face of"> a man, but its end [is] the way of death.
passages.16:26: The life<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> of a worker works for him, for his {hunger}<note: Literally "mouth"> urges him.
passages.16:27: A man of wickedness concocts evil, and his lips [are] like a scorching fire.
passages.16:28: A person of perversity will spread dissent, and he who whispers separates a close friend.
passages.16:29: A person of violence will entice his neighbor and cause him to walk on a way [that is] not good.
passages.16:30: He who winks his eyes [does so in order] to plan perverse things; he who purses his lips will bring evil to pass.
passages.16:31: A crown of glory is gray hair; by a righteous life it is gained.
passages.16:32: He who is slow to anger<note: Literally "nostrils"> [is] better than him who is mighty, and he who controls his spirit than him who captures a city.
passages.16:33: The lot will be cast into the lap, but all of its decisions are from Yahweh.
passages.17:1: Better a dry morsel and quiet with it than a house filled [with] feasts of strife.
passages.17:2: A slave who deals wisely will rule over a child who acts shamefully, and in the midst of brothers he will share his inheritance.
passages.17:3: A crucible [is] for the silver, and a furnace [is] for the gold, but Yahweh will test hearts.
passages.17:4: He who does evil listens to lips of wickedness, [and] the liar gives heed to the tongue of mischief.
passages.17:5: He who mocks the poor insults him who made him; he who rejoices at calamity will not go unpunished.
passages.17:6: The crown of the elderly [are] {grandchildren},<note: Literally "sons of sons"> and the glory of children [is] their fathers.
passages.17:7: {Fine speech}<note: Literally "A lip of fine[ness]"> [is] not becoming a fool, {still less}<note: Literally "only for"> [is] {false speech}<note: Literally "lip of deceit"> for a ruler.
passages.17:8: The bribe [is] a stone of magic in the eyes of its owner;<note: Or "master"> {everywhere}<note: Literally "to all which"> he will turn, he will prosper.
passages.17:9: He who forgives an affront fosters love, but he who waits on a matter will alienate a friend.
passages.17:10: A rebuke strikes him who understands deeper than one hundred blows to a fool.
passages.17:11: An evil person will seek only rebellion, and a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
passages.17:12: [May] a man meet a she-bear robbed of offspring and not a fool in his folly.
passages.17:13: [For] he who returns evil for good, evil will not depart from his house.
passages.17:14: [Like] the release of water [is] the beginning of strife; before it breaks out, stop the quarrel.
passages.17:15: He who justifies the wicked and he who condemns the righteous, the two of them [are] both abominations of Yahweh.
passages.17:16: Why [is] this? A price in the hand of a fool, [in order] to buy wisdom where<note: Hebrew "and"> there is no {sense}.<note: Literally "heart">
passages.17:17: The friend loves at all times<note: Hebrew "time">, but a brother is born for adversity.
passages.17:18: A person who lacks {sense}<note: Literally "heart"> {pledges};<note: Literally "pledges a hand"> he becomes security before his neighbor.
passages.17:19: He who loves transgression loves strife; he who builds his high thresholds seeks destruction.
passages.17:20: He who is crooked of heart<note: Or "mind"> will not find goodness, and he who is perverse, by his tongue he will fall into calamity.
passages.17:21: He who begets a fool, [there is] trouble for him; the father of a fool will not rejoice.
passages.17:22: A cheerful heart is good medicine, but a downcast spirit will dry out bones.
passages.17:23: The wicked will accept a bribe from the lap, [in order] to pervert the ways of justice.
passages.17:24: He who understands sets [his] face [toward] wisdom, but the eyes of a fool, to the end of the earth.<note: Or "land">
passages.17:25: A grief to his father [is] the child of a fool, and bitterness to her who bore him.
passages.17:26: Also, imposing a fine on the righteous is not good, [nor] to flog nobles for uprightness.
passages.17:27: He who spares his sayings knows knowledge, and a cool spirit is a man of understanding.
passages.17:28: Even a fool who keeps silent {shall be considered wise};<note: Literally "wise, he shall be considered"> he who closes his lips [is] intelligent.
passages.18:1: He who is selfish seeks a craving;<note: Or "boundary"> against all sound judgment he shows contempt.
passages.18:2: A fool will not take pleasure in understanding, but in expressing his heart.<note: Or "mind">
passages.18:3: With the coming of wickedness comes contempt also, and with dishonor, disgrace.
passages.18:4: Deep waters [are] words of the mouth of a man; a gushing stream [is] a fountain of wisdom.
passages.18:5: Being partial [to] faces of evil [is] not good, [nor] to subvert the righteous at the judgment.
passages.18:6: The lips of a fool will bring strife, and his mouth calls out for a flogging.
passages.18:7: The mouth of a fool [is] ruin to him, and his lips [are] a snare to his soul.<note: Or "life," or "inner self">
passages.18:8: The words of a whisper [are] like delicious morsels, and they themselves go down [to] inner parts of the body.
passages.18:9: Even he who is slack in his work, he is brother to a master<note: Or "owner"> of destruction.
passages.18:10: A tower of strength is the name of Yahweh; into him<note: Or "it"> the righteous will run and be safe.
passages.18:11: The wealth of the rich [is] {his strong city},<note: Literally "a city of his strength"> and like a wall, it is high in his imagination.
passages.18:12: In the presence of destruction, the heart<note: Or "mind"> of a man will be haughty, but in the presence of honor, humble.
passages.18:13: He who returns a word before he will hear, folly itself [belongs] to him as well as<note: Hebrew "and"> shame.
passages.18:14: The spirit of a man will endure his sickness, but a broken spirit, who may bear it?
passages.18:15: An intelligent {mind}<note: Literally "heart"> will acquire knowledge, and the ear of the wise will seek knowledge.
passages.18:16: The gift of a person will open doors for him, and before the great, it gives him access.
passages.18:17: The first in his dispute is [deemed] righteous, [but] his neighbor will come and examine him.
passages.18:18: The lot will put an end to disputes, and between powerful contenders it will decide.
passages.18:19: A brother who is offended [is worse] than a city of strength, and quarrels [are] like the bars of a fortification.
passages.18:20: From the fruit of a man's mouth, his stomach will be satisfied, as for the yield of his lips, it will satisfy.
passages.18:21: Death and life [are] in the {power}<note: Literally "hand"> of the tongue, and those who love her<note: That is, the power of the tongue> will eat of her fruit.
passages.18:22: He who finds a wife<note: Or "woman"> finds good, and he will obtain favor from Yahweh.
passages.18:23: The poor may speak entreaties, but the rich will answer roughly.
passages.18:24: A man of [many] friends will come to ruin, but there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
passages.19:1: Better a poor person walking in integrity than one who is perverse {in his speech}<note: Literally "in his lips"> and is a fool.
passages.19:2: Also, a life<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> without knowledge is not good, and he who moves quickly with [his] feet {misses the mark}.<note: Or "sins">
passages.19:3: As for the folly of humankind, its way leads to ruin, and against Yahweh his heart<note: Or "mind"> will rage.
passages.19:4: Wealth adds many friends, but the poor will be left by his friends.
passages.19:5: A witness of falsehood will not go unpunished, and he who breathes lies will not escape.
passages.19:6: Many will seek favor before the generous, and everyone [is] the friend of a man of gifts.<note: Hebrew "gift">
passages.19:7: All the brothers of the poor, [if] they hate him, how much more will his friends keep away from him. He pursues [them with] words, [and] they are gone.<note: Or "[when] he pursues words [and] not them">
passages.19:8: He who acquires wisdom loves himself;<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> he who guards understanding [loves] to find good.
passages.19:9: A false witness will not go unpunished, and he who breathes lies will perish.
passages.19:10: For a fool living in luxury is not fitting, [any] more [than it is] for a slave to rule over princes.
passages.19:11: The understanding of a person makes him slow to his {anger},<note: Literally "nostril"> and his glory overlooks offense.
passages.19:12: The rage of a king growls like a lion, but his favor is like dew on the grass.
passages.19:13: A foolish child is a ruin to his father, and the quarreling of a woman<note: Or "wife"> is a continuous dripping.
passages.19:14: A house and wealth [are] an inheritance [from] fathers, but from Yahweh [comes] a woman<note: Or "wife"> who is prudent.
passages.19:15: Laziness will bring on a deep sleep, and a person<note: Or "soul," or "life"> of idleness will suffer hunger.
passages.19:16: He who guards commandments guards his life;<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> he who is careless of his ways will be killed.
passages.19:17: He who lends to Yahweh [is] he who is kind to the poor, and his benefits he will repay to him.
passages.19:18: Discipline your child, for there is hope, but on his destruction do not set your desire.<note: Or "soul," or "inner self">
passages.19:19: A hot-tempered person pays a penalty; if you rescue [him], you will do [it] yet again.
passages.19:20: Listen [to] advice and accept instruction so that you will gain wisdom for your {future}.<note: Literally "after [things]">
passages.19:21: Many plans [are] in the heart<note: Or "mind"> of a man, but the purpose of Yahweh will be established.
passages.19:22: The craving of a man [is] his steadfast loyalty, and [it is] better [to be] poor than a {liar}.<note: Literally "man of lying">
passages.19:23: Fear of Yahweh [leads] to life; he who is filled [with it] will rest--he will not suffer harm.
passages.19:24: A lazy person buries his hand in the dish, and even to his mouth he will not bring it back.
passages.19:25: The scoffer you shall strike, and the simple, may they learn prudence, and reprove the intelligent [and] he will gain knowledge.
passages.19:26: He who does violence to a father, he who chases away a mother, [is] a child who causes shame and brings reproach.
passages.19:27: Cease to listen to instruction, my child, {and you will stray}<note: Literally "[in order] to stray"> from sayings of knowledge.
passages.19:28: A worthless witness will mock justice, and the mouth of the wicked will devour iniquity.
passages.19:29: Judgments<note: Or "Punishments," or "Condemnations"> are prepared for the scoffers, and flogging for the back of fools.
passages.20:1: Wine [is] a mocker, strong drink a brawler, and any who go astray by it are not wise.
passages.20:2: Roaring like the lion [is the] dreaded anger of a king; he who provokes him forfeits his life.<note: Or "soul," or "inner self">
passages.20:3: [It is] honorable for the man to refrain from strife, but every fool will be quick to quarrel.
passages.20:4: The lazy person will not plow in season; he will expect at the harvest, but there [will be] nothing.
passages.20:5: Deep waters [are like] purpose in the heart<note: Or "mind"> of a man, and a man of understanding will draw it<note: Or "her"; referring to "purpose"> out.
passages.20:6: Many a person will proclaim his loyalty [for] himself, but a man [who is] trustworthy, who can find?
passages.20:7: He who walks in his integrity [is] righteous; happy are his children who follow him.
passages.20:8: A king who sits on [the] throne of judgment winnows all evil with his eyes.
passages.20:9: Who will say "I have made my heart<note: Or "mind"> clean; I am pure from my sin"?
passages.20:10: Stone and stone, measure and measure, {both of them}<note: Literally "also [the] two of them"> [are] an abomination of Yahweh.
passages.20:11: Even by his acts, a {young man}<note: Or "young boy," or "adolescent"> will make himself known, whether his acts are pure and upright.
passages.20:12: The ear that hears and the eye that sees, Yahweh has made {them both}.<note: Literally "also [the] two of them">
passages.20:13: Do not love sleep, lest you become poor; open your eyes [and] have plenty bread.
passages.20:14: "Bad, bad," the buyer will say, but [when] one goes to him, then he will boast.
passages.20:15: There is gold and many costly stones, but precious jewels are lips of knowledge.
passages.20:16: Take his garment, for he has given security [to] a stranger, and on behalf of a foreigner--take it as pledge.
passages.20:17: Bread gained by deceit is sweet for the man, but afterward, his mouth will be filled [with] gravel.
passages.20:18: A plan<note: Hebrew "plans"> will be established by advice, and with guidance make war.
passages.20:19: He reveals a secret, he who walks [about with] gossip, and do not associate with a babbler's lips.
passages.20:20: He who curses his father and his mother, his lamp will be extinguished {in the midst of darkness}.<note: Literally "in a pupil of darkness">
passages.20:21: An inheritance acquired [hastily] {at the beginning}<note: Literally "at the first"> will not be blessed at its end.
passages.20:22: Do not say "I will repay evil"; wait for Yahweh and he will deliver you.
passages.20:23: An abomination of Yahweh [is] {a stone and a weight},<note: Literally "a stone and a stone"> and scales of falsehood are not good.
passages.20:24: [Away] from Yahweh are the steps of a strong man, and how will humankind understand his ways?
passages.20:25: [It is] a snare to humankind to say rashly "[It is] holy," and after vows, to scrutinize.
passages.20:26: A wise king winnows the wicked, and he will drive a wheel over them.
passages.20:27: The lamp of Yahweh [is] the spirit<note: Or "soul"> of humankind, he who searches every {innermost part}.<note: Literally "parts of the inmost">
passages.20:28: Loyalty and faithfulness will preserve a king, and he is upheld with the righteousness of his throne.
passages.20:29: The glory of young men [is] their strength,<note: Or "strengthens them"> but the beauty of the aged [is] gray hair.
passages.20:30: The blows of a wound will cleanse evil, as will<note: Hebrew "and"> beatings of the {innermost part}.<note: Literally "parts of the inmost">
passages.21:1: Streams of water [are] the heart<note: Or "mind"> of a king in the hand of Yahweh; {wherever}<note: Literally "upon all that"> he will desire, he will turn.
passages.21:2: Every way of a man is upright in his [own] eyes, but Yahweh weighs hearts.<note: Or "minds">
passages.21:3: Doing righteousness and justice is [more] acceptable to Yahweh than sacrifice.
passages.21:4: Haughtiness of [the] eyes and pride of heart, [the] lamp of the wicked [are] sin.
passages.21:5: The plans of the diligent only [lead] to abundance, but all who are hasty, only to want.
passages.21:6: He who makes treasure by a lying tongue [is a] fleeting vapor [and] seeker<note: Hebrew "seekers"> of death.
passages.21:7: The violence of the wicked will sweep them away, for they refuse to do justice.
passages.21:8: Crooked is the way of a man and a foreigner, but the pure [is] upright [in] his conduct.
passages.21:9: Better to dwell on the corner of a roof than [to] share a house with a woman<note: Or "wife"> of contention.
passages.21:10: The soul<note: Or "soul, life, throat"> of the wicked desires evil; his neighbor will not find mercy in his eyes.
passages.21:11: With the punishment of a scoffer, the simple will become wise, and with the instruction of the wise, he will obtain knowledge.
passages.21:12: The righteous observes the house of the wicked; he throws the wicked to ruin.
passages.21:13: He who closes his ear from the cry of the poor, he also will cry out and not be heard.
passages.21:14: A gift in secret<note: Hebrew "the secret"> will avert {anger},<note: Literally "nostril"> and a {concealed bribe},<note: Literally "bribe in the bosom"> strong wrath.
passages.21:15: [It is] a joy to the righteous to do justice, but dismay to those who do evil.
passages.21:16: Whoever wanders from the way of understanding, in the assembly of the dead<note: Or "Rephaim"> he will rest.
passages.21:17: A man of want [is] he who loves pleasure; he who loves wine and oil<note: Or "fat"> will not become rich.
passages.21:18: A ransom for the righteous is the wicked, and [the] faithless instead of the upright.
passages.21:19: Better to live in a land of wilderness than [with] a wife of quarrels and provocation.
passages.21:20: Precious treasure and oil [are] in the house of the wise, but the foolish person<note: Or "foolish of mankind"> will devour them.<note: Literally "it">
passages.21:21: He who pursues righteousness and kindness will find life, righteousness, and honor.
passages.21:22: To a city of warriors, the wise ascends, and he will bring down the stronghold--its object of trust.
passages.21:23: He who guards his mouth and his tongue, he guards his life<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> from danger.
passages.21:24: The proud, haughty one: "scoffer" [is] his name; he acts with arrogance of pride.
passages.21:25: The craving of a lazy person will kill him, for his hands refuse to work.<note: Or "make">
passages.21:26: {All day}<note: Literally "All the day"> he craves a craving, but the righteous will give and not hold back.
passages.21:27: The sacrifice of the wicked [is] an abomination; how much more when he brings it in divisiveness!
passages.21:28: A false witness will perish, but a man who listens will testify with<note: Hebrew "to the"> success.
passages.21:29: A wicked man is strong in {his countenance},<note: Literally "his face"> but the upright will appoint his paths.
passages.21:30: There is no wisdom, nor understanding, nor counsel to oppose Yahweh.
passages.21:31: A horse is prepared for the day of battle, but to Yahweh [belongs] the victory.
passages.22:1: A {reputation}<note: Literally "name"> [is] to be chosen {rather than}<note: Literally "from"> great riches; {favor is better than silver and gold}.<note: Literally "from silver and from gold, favor [is] better">
passages.22:2: Rich and poor have [much] in common; Yahweh is the maker of all of them.
passages.22:3: The clever sees danger and hides, but the simple go on and suffer.
passages.22:4: The reward of humility [is] the fear of Yahweh-- wealth and honor and life.
passages.22:5: Thorns [and] snares [are] in the way of the perverse; he who guards himself<note: Or "soul," or "life"> will keep away from them.
passages.22:6: Train the child {concerning his way};<note: Literally "on the mouth of his way"> even when he is old, he will not stray from it.
passages.22:7: The rich will rule over the poor, and the borrower is a slave of {the lender}.<note: Literally "the borrower [belonging] to a man">
passages.22:8: He who sows injustice will reap calamity, and the rod of his anger will fail.
passages.22:9: He [who] {is generous}<note: Literally "the generous of eye"> will be blessed, for he gives to the poor from his [own] bread.
passages.22:10: Drive out a scoffer and strife will go out; quarrel and abuse will cease.
passages.22:11: He who loves purity of heart [and has]{gracious speech},<note: Literally "grace of his lips"> his friend [is the] king.
passages.22:12: The eyes of Yahweh keep watch over knowledge, but he will overthrow the words of the faithless.
passages.22:13: A lazy person says "A lion in the street! In the middle of the highway, I shall be killed!"
passages.22:14: A deep pit is the mouth of an {adulteress},<note: Literally "a strange woman"> [he with whom] Yahweh is angry will fall there.
passages.22:15: Folly is bound up in the heart<note: Or "mind"> of a boy;<note: Or "young man," or "adolescent"> [the] rod of discipline will drive it<note: That is, folly> from him.
passages.22:16: He who oppresses the poor [in order] to enrich himself, [or] gives to the rich, {will come to poverty}.<note: Literally "only loss">
passages.22:17: Incline your ear and hear the words of the wise; you shall apply your heart<note: Or "mind"> to my teaching.
passages.22:18: For [it is] pleasant if you guard them {within you};<note: Literally "in your belly/womb"> together they will be ready upon your lips.
passages.22:19: [In order] for your trust to be in Yahweh, I have made [them] known to you {today}<note: Literally "the day">--even<note: Or "only"> you.
passages.22:20: Have I not written for you thirty [sayings] with admonitions and knowledge?
passages.22:21: [In order] to show you what is right--sayings of truth-- [in order] to return a true saying to him who sent you.
passages.22:22: Do not rob the poor because he is poor, and do not crush the afflicted at the gate;
passages.22:23: For Yahweh will plead their case and despoil those who despoil them of life.<note: Or "soul," or "inner self">
passages.22:24: Do not befriend an owner<note: Or "master"> of {anger},<note: Literally "nostril"> and with a man of wrath you shall not associate;
passages.22:25: lest you learn his way and become entangled in a snare to yourself.<note: Or "soul," or "inner self">
passages.22:26: Do not be with those who {give a pledge}<note: Literally "strike a hand"> {by becoming}<note: Literally "in the becomings of"> surety.
passages.22:27: If there is nothing for you to pay,<note: Or "complete"> why will he take your bed from under you?
passages.22:28: Do not remove an ancient boundary marker which your ancestors<note: Or "fathers"> made.
passages.22:29: A man who is skillful in his work, you shall see: before kings, he will serve; he will not serve before the commoners.
passages.23:1: When you sit to eat with a ruler, you shall surely observe what [is] before you,
passages.23:2: and you shall put a knife to your throat if you have a {big appetite}.<note: Literally "lord/master of life">
passages.23:3: Do not desire his delicacies, for<note: Hebrew "and"> it is food of deception.
passages.23:4: Do not tire [in order] to become rich; out of your understanding, [may you] desist.
passages.23:5: Your eyes will {alight}<note: Literally "cause to fly"> on it, but there is nothing [to] it, for suddenly it will make for itself wings like an eagle and it will be exhausted [in] the heavens.
passages.23:6: Do not eat the bread of {the stingy},<note: Literally "stingy of eye"> and do not desire his delicacies.
passages.23:7: For, like hair in his {throat},<note: Literally "soul," or "inner self"> so it is.<note: Or "is he"> "Eat and drink!" he will say to you, but his heart will not be with you.
passages.23:8: Your morsel you have eaten, you will vomit it up, and you will waste your pleasant words.
passages.23:9: In the ears of a fool do not speak, for he will despise the wisdom of your words.
passages.23:10: Do not remove an ancient boundary marker, and on the fields of orphans do not encroach;
passages.23:11: For their redeemer is strong, he himself will plead their cause against you.
passages.23:12: Apply your heart<note: Or "mind"> to instruction, and your ear to sayings of knowledge.
passages.23:13: Do not withhold discipline from a child, if you will beat him with the rod, he will not die.
passages.23:14: As for you, with the rod you shall beat him, and his life<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> you will save from Sheol.<note: A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld>
passages.23:15: My child, if your heart<note: Or "mind"> is wise, my heart will be glad--even me!
passages.23:16: And my {insides}<note: Literally "kidneys"> will rejoice when your lips speak what is upright.
passages.23:17: May your heart<note: Or "mind"> not envy the sinners, but [live] in fear of Yahweh {all day}.<note: Literally "all the day">
passages.23:18: {Surely}<note: Literally "For if"> there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
passages.23:19: You, my child, hear and be wise, and direct your heart<note: Or "mind"> on the road.
passages.23:20: Do not be among drinkers of wine, among gluttonous eaters of {their meat}.<note: Literally "meat for them">
passages.23:21: For the drunkard and gluttonous, they will become poor, and [with] rags, drowsiness will clothe them.
passages.23:22: Listen to your father--he who {gave you life},<note: Literally "caused you to be born"> and do not despise your mother when<note: Or "for, because"> she is old.
passages.23:23: Buy truth and do not sell [it], wisdom and instruction and understanding.
passages.23:24: The father of the righteous will surely rejoice; he who bears a wise person will be happy with him.
