passages.23:25: May your father and your mother be glad, and may she who bore you rejoice.
passages.23:26: My child, may you give your heart<note: Or "mind"> to me, and may your eyes delight in my ways.
passages.23:27: For a deep pit is a prostitute,<note: Or "whore"> and a narrow well is {an adulteress}.<note: Literally "a foreign woman">
passages.23:28: She [is] also like a robber lying in wait, and the faithless among mankind she increases.
passages.23:29: To whom [is] woe? To whom [is] sorrow? To whom [are] quarrels? To whom [is] complaint? To whom [are] wounds without cause? To whom [is] redness of [the] eyes?
passages.23:30: To those who linger over wine, to those who come to try mixed wine.
passages.23:31: Do not look at wine when it is red, when it {sparkles}<note: Literally "gives its eye"> on the cup, going down smoothly.
passages.23:32: {In the end},<note: Literally "end him"> it will bite like a serpent, and it will sting like an adder.
passages.23:33: Your eyes will see strange things, and your heart<note: Or "mind"> will speak perverse things.
passages.23:34: And you will be like him who lies down in the heart of the sea, and like him who lies down on top of a mast.
passages.23:35: "They struck me; I was not hurt. They beat me; I did not know [it]. When I will awake, I will continue; I will seek it again."
passages.24:1: Do not envy men of evil, and do not desire to be with them.
passages.24:2: For their minds will devise violence, and their lips will speak mischief.
passages.24:3: By wisdom a house is built, and by understanding it is established.
passages.24:4: And by knowledge, rooms are filled [with] all riches, precious and pleasant.
passages.24:5: The warrior of wisdom [is] in strength, and a man of knowledge is strong [in] power.
passages.24:6: For with wise guidance you shall make war for yourself, and victory [is] in an abundance of counsel.
passages.24:7: Wisdom [is too] high for fools; at the gate he will not open his mouth.
passages.24:8: He who plans to do evil for<note: Or "to"> himself, they will call [him] "master<note: Or "owner"> of mischief."
passages.24:9: Devising folly [is] a sin, and an abomination to humankind [is] a scoffer.
passages.24:10: [If] you faint on the day of adversity, little [is] your strength.
passages.24:11: Rescue those who are led away to the death and those who stagger to the slaughter. If you hold back,
passages.24:12: if you say, "Look, we do not know this," does not he who weighs hearts perceive [it]? And he who keeps your soul,<note: Or "life," or "inner self"> he knows and will repay humankind according to his deeds.
passages.24:13: My child, eat honey, for [it is] good, and the dripping of the honeycomb [is] sweet to your taste.
passages.24:14: Thus know wisdom for [the sake of] your soul,<note: Or "life," or "inner self"> if you find [it], then there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
passages.24:15: Do not lie in wait [like] an outlaw against the home of the righteous; do not do violence [to] his dwelling place.
passages.24:16: For seven [times] the righteous will fall, but he will rise, but the wicked will be overthrown by calamity.
passages.24:17: While your enemies are falling, do not rejoice; when he trips himself, may your heart<note: Or "mind"> not be glad
passages.24:18: lest Yahweh see and [it] be evil in his eyes, and turn his anger away from him.
passages.24:19: Do not fret because of the evildoers; do not envy the wicked.
passages.24:20: For there will not be a future for the evil; the lamp of the wicked will die out.
passages.24:21: Fear Yahweh, my son, and the king; with those who change, do not associate.
passages.24:22: For suddenly their disaster will come, and the ruin of {both of them},<note: Literally "[the] two of them"> who knows?
passages.24:23: These [sayings] are also for the wise: {Partiality}<note: Literally "acknowledge faces"> in judgment is not good.
passages.24:24: Whoever says to the guilty, "You are righteous," the people will curse him; the nations will abhor him.
passages.24:25: But they who rebuke will have delight, and upon them blessings of goodness will come.
passages.24:26: He will kiss [the] lips, he who gives an honest answer.
passages.24:27: Prepare your work in the street and get it ready for yourself in the field; afterward, then<note: Hebrew "and"> you shall build your house.
passages.24:28: Do not be a witness without cause against your neighbor nor deceive with your lips.
passages.24:29: Do not say, "Just as he has done to me, so shall I do to him; I will pay back the man according to his deed."
passages.24:30: I passed by the field of a lazy person, and over the vineyard of a person lacking {sense};<note: Literally "heart">
passages.24:31: and behold, it was overgrown--all of it was covered [with] thorns, its surface with nettles, and {its stone wall}<note: Literally "a wall of his/its stones"> was broken down.
passages.24:32: Then I myself saw and my heart<note: Or "mind"> considered; I looked, and I took hold of instruction:
passages.24:33: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands for rest,
passages.24:34: and your poverty will come running, and your lack like an armed warrior.
passages.25:1: These are also proverbs of Solomon which officials of Hezekiah king of Judah copied:
passages.25:2: The glory of God<note: Or "gods"> conceals things, but the glory of kings searches out things.
passages.25:3: As heaven is to height and the earth is to depth, so [is] the heart<note: Or "mind"> of kings--there is no searching.
passages.25:4: Remove the dross from silver, and it will become a vessel for the smith.
passages.25:5: Remove the wicked before a king, and his throne will be established in righteousness.<note: Hebrew "in the righteousness">
passages.25:6: Do not promote yourself before the king, and in the place of the great ones do not stand.
passages.25:7: For [it is] better [that] he say to you, "Ascend here," than he humble you before a noble. What your eyes have seen,
passages.25:8: do not hastily bring out to court, for<note: Or "lest"> what will you do at its end, when your neighbor puts you to shame?
passages.25:9: Argue your argument with your neighbor [himself], the secret of another do not disclose,
passages.25:10: lest he who hears shame you and your ill repute will not end.
passages.25:11: Apples of gold in a setting of silver is a matter spoken at<note: Hebrew "on"> its proper time.
passages.25:12: A ring of gold and an ornament of fine gold [is] a rebuke of the wise to the ear of a listener.
passages.25:13: Like the cold of snow on a day<note: Or "at a season"> of harvest [is] a faithful messenger to those who send him, and the soul<note: Or "life," or "inner self"> of his master is refreshed.<note: Or "returned">
passages.25:14: [Like] clouds and wind when there is no rain, [so too is] a man who boasts in a gift of deception.
passages.25:15: {With patience}<note: Literally "With length of face"> a ruler may be persuaded, and a soft tongue will break a bone.<note: Or "strength">
passages.25:16: [If] you find honey, eat what is sufficient for you, lest you have your fill of it and vomit it out.
passages.25:17: Make your foot scarce in the house of your neighbor, lest he become weary of you and hate you.
passages.25:18: [Like] a club and sword and a sharp arrow [is] a man who bears false witness against his neighbor.
passages.25:19: A bad tooth and a lame foot [is] the trust of a faithless person {in a time}<note: Literally "on a day"> of trouble.
passages.25:20: [Like] one who removes a garment on a cold day, [or like] vinegar on natron,<note: A mineral salt found on dry lake beds often used as a preservative.> [is] he who sings songs to a heavy heart.
passages.25:21: If your enemy [is] hungry, feed him bread, and if thirsty, let him drink water.
passages.25:22: For coals of fire you will heap upon his head, and Yahweh will reward you.
passages.25:23: The wind of the north produces rain, and a backbiting tongue, angry faces.
passages.25:24: Better to live upon the corner of a roof than [with] a woman<note: Or "wife"> of contention and [in a] shared house.
passages.25:25: [Like] cold water<note: Hebrew "waters"> upon a weary soul,<note: Or "life," or "inner self"> [so too is] good news from a distant place.
passages.25:26: [Like] a muddied spring or a polluted fountain is the righteous who gives way before the wicked.
passages.25:27: To eat much honey is not good, nor [is] seeking one's honor<note: Hebrew "their honor"> honorable.
passages.25:28: A breached city [where] there is no wall [is like] a man who {has no}<note: Literally "there is no"> self-control for his spirit.
passages.26:1: Like snow in the summer and like rain at the harvest, so honor is not fitting for a fool.
passages.26:2: Like the sparrow [is] to fluttering and like the swallow [is] to flying, so an undeserved curse does not go forth.
passages.26:3: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the back of fools.
passages.26:4: Do not answer a fool according to his folly lest you become like him--even you.
passages.26:5: Answer a fool according to his folly, or else he will be wise in his own eyes.
passages.26:6: [Like] cutting off feet [or] drinking violence, so [is] he who sends messages in the hand of a fool.
passages.26:7: [Like] legs that hang limp from a lame person, so [is] a proverb in the mouth of fools.
passages.26:8: Like binding a stone in a sling, so [is] giving honor to a fool.
passages.26:9: [Like] a thorn that goes up in the hand of a drunkard, so [is] a proverb in the mouth of fools.
passages.26:10: [Like] an archer who wounds everyone, so [is] he who hires a fool or he who hires passersby.
passages.26:11: Like a dog returning to his vomit [is] a fool reverting to his folly.
passages.26:12: [Do] you see a man wise in his own eyes? [There is more] hope for a fool than for him.
passages.26:13: A lazy person says "A lion [is] in the road! A lion among the streets!"
passages.26:14: The door turns on its hinge, and a lazy person on his bed.
passages.26:15: A lazy person buries his hands in the dish; he is [too] tired to return it to his mouth.
passages.26:16: A lazy person is wiser in his eyes than seven who answer discreetly.
passages.26:17: Grabbing onto the ears of a dog passing by [is] one who meddles in a quarrel [that is] not his own.
passages.26:18: Like a maniac who shoots firebrands, arrows, and death,
passages.26:19: so [is] a man who deceives his neighbor, but says "Am I not joking?"
passages.26:20: For lack of wood, a fire goes out, and where there is no whisperer, quarreling will cease.
passages.26:21: [As] charcoal [is] to hot embers and wood [is] to fire, so a man of quarrels [is] to kindling strife.
passages.26:22: The words of a whisperer [are] like delicious morsels, and they go down to the inner parts of the body.
passages.26:23: [Like] {impure silver}<note: Literally "silver of impurities"> which overlays an earthen vessel, [so are] smooth lips and an evil heart<note: Or "mind">.
passages.26:24: On his lips, an enemy will pretend, but {inside}<note: Literally "in his midst"> he will harbor deceit.
passages.26:25: When he makes his voice gracious, do not believe him, for seven abominations [are] in his heart.
passages.26:26: Though hatred is covered with guile, its evil will be exposed in the assembly.
passages.26:27: He who digs a pit, in it he will fall, and he who rolls a stone, on him it will come back.
passages.26:28: A tongue of deceit hates its victim, and a flattering mouth makes ruin.
passages.27:1: Do not boast {about tomorrow},<note: Literally "on the day of tomorrow"> for you do not know what the day will bring.
passages.27:2: May another praise you and not your own mouth, a stranger and not your own lips.
passages.27:3: Heavy [is] a stone and weighty [is] sand, but [the] provocation of a fool [is] heavier than both of them.
passages.27:4: Cruel [is] wrath and overwhelming [is] anger, but who will stand before jealousy?
passages.27:5: Better a rebuke that is open than a love that is hidden.
passages.27:6: The wounds of a friend mean well, but the kisses of an enemy are profane.
passages.27:7: An {appetite}<note: Literally "soul"> that is sated spurns honey, but [to] an {appetite}<note: Literally "soul"> that is ravenous, all bitterness [is] sweet.
passages.27:8: Like a bird that strays from its nest, so is a man who strays from his place.
passages.27:9: Perfume and incense will gladden a heart, and the pleasantness of one's friend [is] {personal advice}.<note: Literally "because of advice of a person">
passages.27:10: As for your friend and a friend of your father, do not forsake [them], and the house of your brother, do not enter on the day of your calamity. Better is a close neighbor than a distant brother.
passages.27:11: Be wise, my child, and make my heart glad, and I will answer him who reproaches me [with] a word.
passages.27:12: [When] the clever sees danger, he hides; the simple go on [and] suffer.
passages.27:13: Take his garment, for he gives surety [to] a stranger, and to {an adulteress}<note: Literally "a foreign woman">--[so] take his pledge.
passages.27:14: He who blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning, a curse will be reckoned to him.
passages.27:15: Dripping constantly on a day of heavy rain and a woman<note: Or "wife"> of contention are alike.
passages.27:16: [In] restraining her, he restrains wind,<note: Or "breath, or "spirit"> and his right hand will grasp oil<note: Or "fat">.
passages.27:17: [As] iron sharpens<note: Or "is united with"> iron, so {one man sharpens another}.<note: Literally "a man sharpens [the] faces of his friend">
passages.27:18: He who tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and he who guards his master<note: Or "lord"> will be honored.
passages.27:19: As the waters [reflect] {face to face},<note: Literally "the faces to the faces"> so the heart of a person [reflects] the person.
passages.27:20: Sheol<note: A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld> and Abaddon<note: Poetic synonym for "Sheol." Only mentioned in the ot in relation to Sheol, the grave, or death.> will not be satisfied, and the eyes of a person will not be satisfied [either].
passages.27:21: A crucible [is] for the silver, and a furnace for the gold, but a man [is tested by] the mouth of him who praises him.
passages.27:22: If you crush a fool in the mortar with the pestle {along with}<note: Or "in the midst of"> the crushed grain, it will not drive folly from upon him.
passages.27:23: You will surely know the {condition}<note: Literally "faces"> of your flock; your heart<note: Or "mind"> attends to the herds.
passages.27:24: For riches [are] not forever, nor a crown for generation [after] generation.
passages.27:25: When the grass is gone, then green growth will appear, and the herbs of the mountains will be gathered.
passages.27:26: Lambs [will be] your clothing, and goats the price of the field.
passages.27:27: And [there will be] enough goats' milk for your food, for [the] food of your household and [the] {nourishment}<note: Literally "life"> of your maidservants.
passages.28:1: The wicked flee, but no one pursues, but the righteous is bold like a lion.
passages.28:2: By the rebellion of a land, her rulers increase, but by a person of intelligence who knows justice, it will last.
passages.28:3: A man [who is] poor and oppresses the impoverished [is] a beating rain {that leaves}<note: Literally "and there is"> no food.
passages.28:4: Those who forsake instruction will praise the wicked, but they who guard instruction will struggle against them.
passages.28:5: Men of evil do not understand justice, but seekers of Yahweh understand completely.<note: Or "everything">
passages.28:6: Better [to be] poor and walking in one's integrity than to be crooked of ways when one [is] rich.
passages.28:7: He who keeps instruction [is] a child of understanding, but the companion of gluttons will shame his father.
passages.28:8: He who augments his wealth with interest and with usury gathers it for him who is kind to the poor.
passages.28:9: He who turns his ear from listening to instruction, even his prayer [is] an abomination.
passages.28:10: He who misleads the upright onto the way of evil, into his pits he will fall. But as for the blameless, they will inherit good.
passages.28:11: A man of wealth [is] wise in his own eyes, but the intelligent poor sees through him.
passages.28:12: When the righteous triumphs, great [is] the glory, but with [the] rising of the wicked, a person will be hidden.
passages.28:13: He who conceals his transgression will not prosper, but he who confesses and forsakes will obtain mercy.
passages.28:14: Happy is the person who fears continuously, but he who is stubborn of heart,<note: Or "mind"> will fall into calamity.
passages.28:15: [Like] a roaring lion and a charging bear [is] a wicked ruler over a poor people.
passages.28:16: A ruler who lacks understanding is<note: Hebrew "and"> a cruel oppressor, [but] those who hate unjust gain will have long<note: Or "prolong"> days.
passages.28:17: A person who is burdened with [the] blood of {another},<note: Literally "life"> until death he will flee; do not take hold of him.
passages.28:18: He who walks in integrity will be safe, but he who takes crooked paths will fall in one.
passages.28:19: He who tills his ground will have plenty bread, but he who follows fantasies will have plenty [of] poverty.
passages.28:20: A man of faithfulness [has] abundant blessings, but he who hurries to become rich will not go unpunished.
passages.28:21: {Showing partiality}<note: Literally "Recognizing faces"> [is] not good, and over a morsel of bread, a strong man will do wrong.
passages.28:22: He who hurries for wealth is {a man with an evil eye},<note: Literally "a man of evil of eye"> but he does not know that poverty will come upon him.
passages.28:23: He who rebukes a person will afterward find [more] favor than he who flatters [with the] tongue.
passages.28:24: He who robs his father and his mother and says, "There is no crime," is partner to a man who corrupts.
passages.28:25: The {greedy person}<note: Literally "wide soul"> will stir up strife, but he who trusts in Yahweh will be enriched.
passages.28:26: He who trusts in his own heart<note: Or "mind," or "sense"> is a fool, but he who walks in wisdom will be saved.
passages.28:27: [For] he who gives to the poor, there is no lacking, but [for] he<note: Hebrew "those"> who turns his eyes, [there are] many curses.
passages.28:28: With [the] rising of the wicked, humankind will be hidden, and with their perishing, [the] righteous will multiply.
passages.29:1: A man who is reproved, being stubborn of neck-- suddenly he will be broken, and there will not be healing.
passages.29:2: When the righteous are numerous, the people will rejoice, but when the wicked are ruling, people will groan.
passages.29:3: A man who loves wisdom will make his parents glad, but the friend of prostitutes<note: Or "whores"> will squander his wealth.
passages.29:4: By justice a king gives stability [to] a land, but a man of bribes will ruin it.
passages.29:5: A strong man who flatters his neighbor is spreading a net for his feet.
passages.29:6: In transgression, an evil man [is] a snare, but [the] righteous will sing and rejoice.<note: Hebrew "he will rejoice">
passages.29:7: [The] righteous knows [the] case of the poor, but [the] wicked does not understand knowledge.
passages.29:8: Men of scoffing set a city aflame, but the wise turn away wrath.
passages.29:9: [If] a wise man goes to court with a foolish man, then there is rankling and ridicule,<note: Hebrew "there is ridicule"> but there is no relief.
passages.29:10: Men of blood hate [the] blameless, and they seek the life of the upright.<note: Or "soul," or "inner self">
passages.29:11: A fool gives all his breath,<note: Or "spirit"> but [the] wise holds back in quiet.
passages.29:12: A ruler listening to a word of falsehood, all his officials are wicked.
passages.29:13: The poor and a man of oppression have [this] in common: Yahweh gives {light to the eyes of them both}.<note: Literally "light of the eyes of the two of them">
passages.29:14: A king who judges with truthfulness [to] the poor, his throne will be established forever.
passages.29:15: As for a rod and reproof, they<note: Hebrew "it"> will give wisdom, but a neglected child is disgraced [by] his mother.
passages.29:16: With the increase of the wicked, transgression will increase, but the righteous will look on his downfall.
passages.29:17: Discipline your children, and they will give you rest, and they will give delight to your soul.<note: Or "life," or "inner self">
passages.29:18: When there is no prophecy, the people cast off restraint, but as for he who guards instruction, happiness [is] his.
passages.29:19: By words, a servant is not disciplined, for he will understand, but there is no giving heed.
passages.29:20: You see a man who is hasty in his words: [there is more] hope for a fool than him.
passages.29:21: He who pampers his servant from childhood, {arrogance will be his end}.<note: Literally "and its/his end will be arrogance">
passages.29:22: A man of anger will stir strife, and the owner of anger, much transgression.
passages.29:23: The pride of a person will bring him humiliation, and the lowly of spirit will obtain honor.
passages.29:24: Being a partner with a thief is hating one's life;<note: Or "soul," or "inner self"> a curse he will hear, but not disclose.
passages.29:25: The fear of a person will lay a snare, but he who trusts in Yahweh will be secure.
passages.29:26: Many are those who seek the {favor}<note: Literally "faces"> of a ruler, but from Yahweh {one obtains justice}.<note: Literally "[comes] justice for a man">
passages.29:27: A man of injustice is an abomination to the righteous, but the {upright}<note: Literally "upright of way"> is an abomination to the wicked.
passages.30:1: The words of Agur, son of Yakeh, the oracle. Thus says the man to Ithiel, to Ithiel, and Ucal:<note: Or "I am weary, O God; I am weary, O God, and worn out">
passages.30:2: Certainly I [am more] stupid than a man, and the understanding of humankind [is] not for me.
passages.30:3: And I have not learned wisdom, nor will I know knowledge of the Holy One.<note: Or "holy ones">
passages.30:4: Who has ascended [to] heaven and come down? Who has gathered [the] wind in the hollow of his hand? Who has wrapped water in a<note: Hebrew "the"> garment? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What [is] his name and what is the name of his child? For [surely] you know.
passages.30:5: Every word of God [is] flawless; he [is] a shield for him who takes refuge in him.
passages.30:6: Do not add to his words lest he rebuke you and you be found a liar.
passages.30:7: Two things I ask from you; do not deny me before I die:
passages.30:8: Keep falsehood and a {lying word}<note: Literally "word of a lie"> far from me; do not give me poverty or wealth; provide me [with] food [only for] my need.
passages.30:9: Or else I will be satisfied and will deny [him] and say "Who [is] Yahweh?" Or<note: Or "Lest"> I will be poor and will steal and profane the name of my God.
passages.30:10: Do not slander a servant to his master, or else he will curse you and you will be guilty.
passages.30:11: [There is] a generation [that] will curse its father, and its mother it will not bless.
passages.30:12: [There is] a generation [that is] pure in its own eyes, but from its filthiness it will not be cleansed.
passages.30:13: [There is] a generation--how lofty [are] their eyes! And their eyelids they will lift.
passages.30:14: [There is] a generation whose teeth [are] swords, and its jawbones, knives, [in order] to devour the poor from the earth<note: Or "land"> and the needy from humankind.
passages.30:15: For the leech, [there are] two daughters; "Give, give!" [they cry]. As for three of these, they are not satisfied; as for four, they do not say enough.
passages.30:16: Sheol<note: A term for the place where the dead reside, i.e., the Underworld> and barrenness of womb, the land is not satisfied [with] water, and fire does not say "enough!"
passages.30:17: The eye [that] mocks a father and scorns the obedience of a mother-- the ravens of the valley will peck it out, and the offspring of vultures will eat it.
passages.30:18: Three of these are [too] wonderful for me, and four, I do not understand them:
passages.30:19: the way of the eagle in the sky, the way of a snake on a rock, the way of a ship in the heart of the sea, and the way of a man with a young woman.
passages.30:20: This is the way of a woman committing adultery: she eats and wipes her mouth, and says "I have not done wrong."
passages.30:21: Under three [things] the earth<note: Or "land"> trembles, and under four, it is not able to bear up:
passages.30:22: under a slave when he becomes king, and a fool when he is satisfied [with] food;
passages.30:23: under an unloved woman when she gets married, and a maid when she succeeds her mistress.
passages.30:24: There [are] four small things on the earth, and they [are] {exceedingly wise}:<note: Literally "wise [ones] from wise [ones]">
passages.30:25: The ants [are] a people [who are] not strong, yet they prepare their food in the summer;
passages.30:26: the badgers [are] a people [who are] not mighty, yet they set their house on the rock;
passages.30:27: there is no king for the locust, yet it marches in rank;
passages.30:28: a lizard you [can] seize with hands, yet it is in palaces of kings.
passages.30:29: There [are] three [things] that are magnificent of stride, and four that are magnificent [when] moving:
passages.30:30: a mighty lion among the beasts,<note: Hebrew "beasts"> but he will not turn back from {any face};<note: Literally "faces of all">
passages.30:31: a strutting rooster or he-goat, and a king [whose] army [is] with him.
passages.30:32: If you have been foolish by exalting yourself, and if you have devised evil, [put your] hand to [your] mouth.
passages.30:33: For pressing milk produces curd, and pressing the nose produces blood, so pressing {anger}<note: Literally "nostrils"> produces strife.
passages.31:1: The words of Lemuel, [the] king--an oracle that his mother taught him:
passages.31:2: What, my son? And what, my son in my womb? And what, son of my vows?
passages.31:3: Do not give your strength to the women, and your ways to destroy kings.
passages.31:4: [It is] not for the kings, O Lemuel; drinking wine [is] not for the kings, nor [is] strong drink for rulers.
passages.31:5: Or else he will drink and forget what has been decreed, and he will pervert the rights<note: Hebrew "right"> of all the {afflicted}.<note: Literally "sons of affliction">
passages.31:6: Give strong drink to him who is perishing, and wine to those {in bitter distress}.<note: Literally "to bitterness of soul">
passages.31:7: He will drink and forget his poverty, and his misery he will not remember [any] more.
passages.31:8: Open your mouth for the mute, for the rights<note: Hebrew "right"> of all the {needy}.<note: Literally "the sons of the needy">
passages.31:9: Open your mouth, judge righteousness, and defend [the] poor and needy.
passages.31:10: A woman<note: Or "wife"> of excellence,<note: Or "strength," or "valor," or "ability," or "efficiency"> who will find? For her worth [is] far more than precious jewels.
passages.31:11: The heart of her husband<note: Or "lord"> trusts in her, and gain he will not lack.
passages.31:12: She does him good, but not harm all the days of her life.
passages.31:13: She seeks wool and flax, and she works with the diligence of {her hands}.<note: Literally "her palms">
passages.31:14: She is like the ships of a merchant; from far off she brings her food;<note: Or "bread">
passages.31:15: And she arises while [it is] still night, and gives food to her household, and tasks to her servant girls.
passages.31:16: She considers a field and buys it, from the fruit of {her hand}<note: Literally "her palm"> she plants a vineyard.
passages.31:17: She girds her waist in strength, and makes her arms strong.
passages.31:18: She perceives that her merchandise [is] good; her lamp does not go out in the night.
passages.31:19: Her hands she puts onto the distaff,<note: A stick or spindle onto which wool or flax is wound in preparation for spinning> and her palms hold a spindle.
passages.31:20: Her palm she opens to the poor, and her hand she reaches [out] to the needy.
passages.31:21: She does not fear for her house [when] it snows, for {her entire household}<note: Literally "all her house, household"> is clothed [in] crimson.
passages.31:22: She makes for herself coverings; her clothing [is] fine linen and purple.
passages.31:23: Her husband<note: Or "lord"> is known at the gates, in his seat among the elders of the land.
passages.31:24: Linen garments she makes and sells, and she supplies sashes for the merchants.
passages.31:25: Strength and dignity are her clothing, and she laughs {at the future}.<note: Literally "to the day/time coming after">
passages.31:26: She opens her mouth with wisdom, and instruction of kindness [is] upon her tongue.
passages.31:27: She looks after the ways of her household, and the bread of idleness she will not eat.
passages.31:28: Her children rise and consider her happy, her husband<note: Or "lord"> [also], and he praises her;
passages.31:29: "Many daughters have done excellence,<note: Or "strength," or "valor," or "ability," or "efficiency"> but {you surpass}<note: Literally "you ascend over"> all of them."
passages.31:30: Charm<note: Hebrew "The charm"> [is] deceit and beauty<note: Hebrew "the beauty"> [is] vain;<note: Or "vapor," or "emptiness," or "breath"> [but] a woman who fears Yahweh shall be praised.
passages.31:31: Give to her from the fruit of her hand, and may they praise her works in the city gates.
